0: (CNN) Words can change meaning over time -- especially when they are spoken by politicians. Just ask Bill Clinton to define "is." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Literally" was once used, exclusively, to introduce or punctuate a point meant to be taken in literal terms. But by 2013, enough people were using it interchangeably with "metaphorically" that even leading grammar pedants threw up their hands (literally?), and the Merriam-Webster and Cambridge dictionaries expanded their definitions. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Donald Trump has, throughout his campaign, tested the pliability of rhetoric and language, sometimes to underline an affirmative point, but more often of late -- and in particular on Friday morning -- as a tool for walking back damaging (or straight-up false ) assertions. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR On Wednesday, the Republican nominee launched a new round of criticism against President Barack Obama and Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, the former secretary of state, calling Obama the "founder" of ISIS and Clinton its "co-founder." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Given multiple opportunities to allow that his language had been hyperbolic or, yes, metaphoric, Trump refused. On Thursday, conservative radio host Hugh Hewitt practically begged him to narrow his definition. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Last night, you said the President was the founder of ISIS. I know what you meant," Hewitt said . "You meant that he created the vacuum, he lost the peace." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR But Trump wouldn't play along. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "No, I meant he's the founder of ISIS," Trump said. "I do. He was the most valuable player. I give him the most valuable player award. I give her, too, by the way, Hillary Clinton." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Hewitt again: "But he's not sympathetic to them. He hates them. He's trying to kill them." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "I don't care," Trump said. "He was the founder. His, the way he got out of Iraq was that that was the founding of ISIS, okay?" NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Sensing progress, Hewitt probed a little further, and Trump seemed to be coming around, saying that if Obama "would have done things properly (in managing the withdrawal from Iraq), you wouldn't have had ISIS." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "That's true," Hewitt said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Therefore," Trump added, closing the circle, "he was the founder of ISIS." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A day of furious -- if somewhat puzzled -- fact-checking followed. The reviews were unanimous. No, Obama was not the founder of ISIS. That title mostly belongs to Abu Musab Al-Zarqawi, who led al Qaeda in Iraq before being killed in an American airstrike. The group rebranded after his death, becoming ISIS, and under the guidance of Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi has capitalized on a series of missteps by both the George W. Bush and Obama administrations -- along with a civil war in Syria and Iraqi government failures -- to create a new global terror state. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR By Friday morning, as the backlash to Trump's comments was again threatening to knock out the potential to generate any positive news or electoral momentum, he began a familiar process -- the walk-back. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR And true to this latest narrative's grammarian nightmare theme, Trump did it with a confounding declaration. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The term is precise. The dictionaries match the vernacular. It is the use of irony, of pointedly saying the opposite of what you mean in order to make a rhetorical point. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Taken in a sarcastic light, Trump's words would be amount to a mockery of... Trump's words.
